Contradict fact: The claim that "President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election" is contradicted by the fact that at least one ambassador, Victor Ashe, was asked to continue serving in his post by the Obama administration.
Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as an exaggeration because it implies that every single Bush-appointed ambassador was fired, when there were exceptions to this practice.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the provided claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times because it does not accurately represent the full reality of the situation, as there were exceptions to the practice of firing all politically-appointed ambassadors.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide evidence for the assertion that every single Bush-appointed ambassador was fired by President Obama.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all politically-appointed ambassadors are fired upon the election of a new president, which is not always the case.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not present an alternative explanation for the removal of ambassadors.
